conclusion: Use principles of thermodynamics and ideal gas law to calculate heat exchanged.
Initial state at point A with temperature -73°C and volume 1 m³; final state at point C with temperature 273 K and volume 4 m³.
Internal energy change from state A to C is 200 J.
Initial pressure at state A is 3 x 10⁵ P_a; final pressure at state C is 1 x 10⁵ P_a.
Change in volume from state A to C is 3 m³.
Apply first law of thermodynamics to find heat Q; work done is calculated using W = P ΔV.
Work done is 0 since initial and final pressures are the same.
Initial temperature at state A is -73°C = 293 K; final temperature at state C is 273 K.
Calculate heat Q using Q = N_A × m × ΔT.
Heat Q can be calculated as Q = N_A × m × (ΔT - ΔV) since mass is constant.
Substitute values into equation to find heat Q.
Final temperature at state C is 273 K; initial temperature at state A is -73°C = 293 K.
Substitute values into equation to find heat Q.
Verify calculations to ensure they match given values.
The heat Q exchanged is 200 J.
